modules.title: Module 1: Introduction to React
modules.description: Learn the basics of React and how to set up your first project.

lessons.title: What is React?
lessons.theory: React is a JavaScript library for building user interfaces. It is maintained by Facebook and a community of individual developers and companies. React allows developers to create large web applications that can change data, without reloading the page. The main purpose of React is to be fast, scalable, and simple.
lessons.code:
// React is a library, not a framework.
// It focuses on the View layer of MVC.

lessons.title: JSX
lessons.theory: JSX stands for JavaScript XML. It allows us to write HTML in React. JSX makes it easier to write and add HTML in React. By using JSX, we can write HTML structures in the same file as JavaScript code. Under the hood, JSX is converted to `React.createElement` calls.

lessons.title: Components
lessons.theory: Components are independent and reusable bits of code. They serve the same purpose as JavaScript functions, but work in isolation and return HTML. Components come in two types: Class components and Function components. Modern React focuses heavily on Function components.

project.title: Hello React
project.description: Create a simple React component that displays a greeting.

modules.title: Module 2: Props & State
modules.description: Understand how data flows and how components remember things.

lessons.title: Props
lessons.theory: Props (short for properties) are arguments passed into React components. Props are passed to components via HTML attributes. React Props are read-only! You will get an error if you try to change their value.

quiz.question: Can you modify props inside a component?

lessons.title: State
lessons.theory: React components has a built-in state object. The state object is where you store property values that belong to the component. When the state object changes, the component re-renders.

project.title: Counter App
project.description: Build a counter component that increments and decrements a number.

modules.title: Module 3: React Hooks
modules.description: Master the powerful hooks introduced in React 16.8.

lessons.title: useState Hook
lessons.theory: The `useState` hook allows us to track state in a function component. It accepts an initial state and returns two values: the current state and a function that updates it.

quiz.question: What does useState return?
options: An array with state and update function

lessons.title: useEffect Hook
lessons.theory: The `useEffect` hook allows you to perform side effects in your components. Some examples of side effects are: fetching data, directly updating the DOM, and timers. It runs after every render by default, but can be controlled with a dependency array.

quiz.question: When does useEffect run if the dependency array is empty []?

project.title: Digital Clock
project.description: Use useState and useEffect to create a live digital clock.

lessons.title: Handling Events
lessons.theory: React events are named using camelCase, rather than lowercase. With JSX you pass a function as the event handler, rather than a string.

quiz.question: How are events named in React?

lessons.title: Conditional Rendering
lessons.theory: In React, you can create distinct components that encapsulate behavior you need. Then, you can render only some of them, depending on the state of your application. Common methods include the `if` statement, logical `&&` operator, and ternary operator `? :`.

quiz.question: Which operator is commonly used for inline conditional rendering?

project.title: Login Toggle
project.description: Create a button that toggles between 'Login' and 'Logout' states.

modules.title: Module 5: Lists & Forms
modules.description: Working with arrays and user input.

lessons.title: Rendering Lists
lessons.theory: In React, you will render lists with some type of loop. The JavaScript `map()` array method is generally the preferred method.

quiz.question: Which array method is best for rendering lists in React?

lessons.title: Keys
lessons.theory: Keys help React identify which items have changed, are added, or are removed. Keys should be given to the elements inside the array to give the elements a stable identity. The key should be unique among siblings.

quiz.question: Why are keys important in lists?
options: They help React track elements efficiently

lessons.title: Forms
lessons.theory: In HTML, form elements usually maintain their own state. In React, mutable state is typically kept in the state property of components, and only updated with `setState()`. These are called 'Controlled Components'.

quiz.question: What is a Controlled Component?
options: A component where React state controls the input value

project.title: Todo List
project.description: Build a Todo app where you can add items via a form and list them.

lessons.title: React Router
lessons.theory: React Router is a standard library for routing in React. It enables the navigation among views of various components in a React Application, allows changing the browser URL, and keeps the UI in sync with the URL.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of React Router?
options: To handle navigation in a Single Page App

lessons.title: Context API
lessons.theory: React Context provides a way to pass data through the component tree without having to pass props down manually at every level. It is useful for global data like themes, user authentication, etc.

project.title: Theme Switcher
project.description: Use Context API to toggle between Light and Dark themes across an app.
